channel.title: CSIS — Analysis (custom RSS)
channel.description: Auto-generated RSS feed for CSIS Analysis pages.

item.title: If the Pentagon Wants More Speed and Scale, It Should Be a Better Customer
item.description: As the Department of War modernizes its acquisition process to optimize speed and scale, it should also think about how the Pentagon can be a better customer. Industry has to have trust that the military will stick to its budget plans.

item.title: Trump’s Caribbean Campaign: The Data Behind the Developing Conflict
item.description: The United States and Venezuela teeter on the brink of war. Twelve charts and tables lay out where we are, how we got here, and how a conflict might play out.

item.title: Waiting for the Supremes Part II
item.description: This week, Bill Reinsch examines the significance of the Supreme Court hearing on President Trump’s use of the International Economic Emergency Powers Act, outlining the key legal arguments and assessing the potential outcomes.

item.title: Trade Deals and a New Chapter for American Nuclear?
item.description: A slew of recently announced trade deals and investment agreements could amount to the most ambitious U.S. government action to support nuclear energy in decades, but key questions remain.

item.title: Rhetoric vs. Reality: The Philippines, ASEAN, and the South China Sea
item.description: Manila’s expanding defense partnerships may reveal a pragmatic strategy beyond relying on ASEAN’s consensus-based diplomacy.

item.title: Avoiding Catastrophe: The Importance of Privacy when Leveraging AI and Machine Learning for Disaster Management
item.description: Leveraging data effectively reduces disaster harms – but the data must be used in a responsible way that prioritizes security and privacy.

item.title: Ryan Berg in Foreign Policy: Toppling Maduro Without Boots on the Ground
item.description: Americas Program Director argues that rather than a ground invasion aimed at regime change, the pressure campaign by the Trump administration may lead to regime collapse, an outcome that is worth pursuing.

item.title: What’s Next for AGOA?
item.description: The African Growth and Opportunity Act, the flagship U.S. trade agreement with Africa, has expired. As Washington debates the bill’s future, its uneven track record offers lessons on how to effectively strengthen U.S.-Africa commercial engagement moving forward.

item.title: Who Controls the Wrench: The Debate Over the “Right to Repair”
item.description: It is often a challenge for the government to repair its own equipment because it lacks access to the intellectual property necessary for sustainment. But there are pros and cons to the government having the right to repair.
